{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3485446,"name":"John Hascall (he)","username":"john3928","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T05:14:54.926Z","cooked":"

It’s been a long time (before my time) since we used a “Button Box” instead of an Xbox controller or two. But this year’s game has me pondering. There are (potentially) 18 interesting locations around your reef, and potentially 4-6 interesting heights each side there. Not to mention potentially processor scoring, Net scoring, player station intake, possibly 2 floor intakes. And whatever you do for climb. That’s a lot of possibilities!

Ignoring what the driver will drive with, what do you think to operate the robot;

  • Button Box
  • Gamepad
  • Both
  • Something else
  • Don’t know yet
0 voters

Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-17T13:42:33.181Z","cooked":"

Current plan: A button on the driver xbox controller that, when pressed and held, aligns to the nearest scoring position.

Backup if that doesn’t work intuitively: A button board with a 12-position dial that selects the scoring position. Operator watches the reef and selects the position. Driver still has a button which auto-aligns to whatever position was selected.

Seems to me “closest” scoring position is a little hard to discern when there are 3 “horizontal” positions per side (esp if your robot is on the far side. Be pretty annoying if it pulled up to the algae position when you wanted to do an algae

We decided that instead of auto-aligning for algae removal, we’d just build a wider algae remover.

Point taken though, making sure they hit the correct left/right side will be key.

Current algorithm running in sim is “select side by closest angle first, then select left/right by x/y position of robot”. Seems to… work?

Cool!

One of our students made a button box to play with. He even made a little game to play with it to get used to the call outs. I think it’s a pretty cool project, and (in my opinion) it’s worth following along!

FRC Team 1710 | 2025 Build Thread | Open Alliance FRC Open Alliance
Early Build Season Programming This year’s game is amazing for programmers. There are AprilTags absolutely everywhere (which will hopefully make full-field localization easy), plenty of opportunities for automating scoring processes, and maybe even some fun flight trajectory math to do with algae. My programmers and I are super excited to try and automate as much of the scoring process as we can, and here’s how we plan on doing it. Camera Placement This year, we’re planning on having 5 cameras …
